description: From Middle English court, from Old French cort, curt, from Latin cōrtem (accusative of cōrs), ultimately from cohors. Doublet of cohort.

definitionGroups.group: An enclosed space; a courtyard; an uncovered area shut in by the walls of a building, or by different buildings; also, a space opening from a street and nearly surrounded by houses; a blind alley.

entries.meaning: (Australia, US) A street with no outlet, a cul-de-sac.
(Hong Kong, only used in names) A housing estate under the House Ownership Scheme.
(Hong Kong, only used in names) An apartment building, or a small development of several apartment buildings.
The residence of a sovereign, prince, nobleman, or other dignitary; a palace.
examples: The noblemen visited the queen in her court.

entries.meaning: The collective body of persons composing the retinue of a sovereign or person high in authority; all the surroundings of a sovereign in his regal state.
examples: The queen and her court traveled to the city to welcome back the soldiers.

entries.meaning: Any formal assembling of the retinue of a sovereign.
Attention directed to a person in power; behaviour designed to gain favor; politeness of manner; civility towards someone
The hall, chamber, or place, where justice is administered.
examples: Many famous criminals have been put on trial in this court.

entries.meaning: The persons officially assembled under authority of law, at the appropriate time and place, for the administration of justice; an official assembly, legally met together for the transaction of judicial business; a judge or judges sitting for the hearing or trial of cases.
examples: The court started proceedings at 11 o'clock.

entries.meaning: (often capitalized) The judge or judges or other judicial officer presiding in a particular matter, particularly as distinguished from the counsel or jury, or both.
The session of a judicial assembly.
examples: The court is now in session.

entries.meaning: Any jurisdiction, civil, military, or ecclesiastical.

definitionGroups.group: (sports) A place arranged for playing the games of tennis, basketball, handball, badminton, volleyball, squash and some other games

entries.meaning: one of the two divisions of a tennis, badminton or volleyball court, in which the player or players of each team play
examples: The photograph at left captures a great serve by Dr. Sadowsky, who will never forget one of Bobby Riggs's serves, which had such a great spin that it landed in his court and bounced back to the other side of the net before he had a chance to return it.

verbs.description: court (third-person singular simple present courts, present participle courting, simple past and past participle courted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To seek to achieve or win.
examples: He was courting big new accounts that previous salesman had not attempted.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To risk (a consequence, usually negative).
examples: He courted controversy with his frank speeches.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To try to win a commitment to marry from.
(transitive) To engage in behavior leading to mating.
examples: The bird was courting by making an elaborate dance.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attempt to attract.
(transitive) To invite by attractions; to allure; to attract.
examples: Synonyms: charm, entrance; see also Thesaurus:allure

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attempt to gain alliance with.
(intransitive) To engage in activities intended to win someone's affections.
examples: Synonyms: romance, solicit; see also Thesaurus:woo
She's had a few beaus come courting.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To engage in courtship behavior.
examples: In this season, you can see many animals courting.
